content: The "Federal Youth Coordination Act" is established with a short title. It outlines the establishment and membership of the Act. The Federal Youth Development Council, composed of various federal officials, is established under the Federal Youth Coordination Act. The Federal Youth Development Council is established under the Federal Youth Coordination Act. The Council includes members appointed by the President from various organizations to serve for 2-year terms, with the Chairperson designated by the President. Meetings are held at least 4 times a year. The Federal Youth Development Council, established under the Federal Youth Coordination Act, holds meetings at least 4 times a year, with the first meeting scheduled not less than 6 months after the Act's enactment. The Federal Youth Development Council, established under the Federal Youth Coordination Act, holds meetings at least 4 times a year, with the first meeting scheduled not less than 6 months after the Act's enactment. The council's duties are outlined in Section 3. The Federal Youth Development Council is responsible for ensuring communication among agencies serving youth, assessing their needs and federal programs, setting goals, making resource allocation recommendations, identifying at-risk youth populations, and developing a plan with common indicators of youth development. The Federal Youth Development Council aims to develop a plan with common indicators of youth well-being, assist agencies in coordinating to achieve goals, collaborate on model programs for special populations, and solicit input from various stakeholders. The Federal Youth Development Council collaborates with researchers, State and local government officials, and Federal agencies to conduct high-quality research, identify model programs, provide technical assistance, and fund additional research as needed. The Federal Youth Development Council has the authority to employ necessary staff and request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in carrying out its duties. It can also use the United States mails and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. Additionally, the Council can provide assistance to states as needed. The Federal Youth Development Council can provide technical assistance and grants to States for coordinating youth efforts. Priority is given to States with existing interagency coordination efforts, plans to work with local youth councils, involvement of nonprofit organizations, and inclusion of young people. The State council should demonstrate the inclusion of young people, especially those in disadvantaged situations. SEC. 7. REPORT. The Council must submit an annual report to the President and Congress within 1 year of its first meeting, and for the following 4 years. The report should include recent research on youth wellbeing, assess youth needs and objectives, recommend ways to improve coordination among federal programs serving youth, and suggest policies integration across agencies at different levels. The Council's annual report must include recommendations for legislation and administrative actions to coordinate policies across Federal, State, and local levels. It should also summarize actions taken to facilitate collaboration on youth programs and include input from identified groups. The Council will terminate 60 days after submitting its final report. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 2005-2009 to implement this Act.
